definition: Reorganizing content for logical flow, coherence, and effectiveness, including reordering sections, strengthening transitions, and ensuring argument progression

positive_examples: Structural editing moved the backstory from chapter one to chapter three for better pacing.
The structural edit recommended splitting the overlong middle section into two chapters.
Structural editing identified that the argument's strongest point was buried in paragraph twelve.
The editor's structural pass added signposting and transitions between major sections.
Structural editing identified that the chronological order obscured the thematic argument.
training_hints.disambiguation: Purposeful reorganization for effectiveness, not arbitrary rearrangement
